text: Social interactions allow for information dissemination about technologies, products, job opportunities, and beliefs (Jackson, 2010; Jackson, 2011). In finance, a substantial body of evidence shows that information sharing with peers plays an important role for investment decision-making, including stock market participation and portfolio choice (e.g., Duflo & Saez, 2003; Hong, et al., 2004; Bursztyn, et al., 2014; Li, 2015). In social settings, however, individuals are selective about the information they want to share with others. For example, people may tend to boast about good stock trades, favoring the transmission of appealing but inaccurate ideas about active trading (Shiller, 1995; Shiller, 2015), or they may try to convince others that they are wealthier or more intelligent than what they really are.3 Despite extensive research on the effects of social interactions on investment choices, the role that selective communication has on the diffusion of trading strategies remains largely unexplored.4 In this paper, we use data from a large- scale financial education program to study the effects from noisy word-of-mouth communication on the decision to participate in the stock market. We show that biased signals from peers disproportionally attract uninformed individuals to equity trading. These investors overestimate the value of active trading and generate inferior returns once they enter the stock market. Canonical models of social learning assume that peer choices are perfectly observed by members of the social network (Banerjee, 1992; Bikhchandani, et al., 1992). In practice, peer preferences and outcomes are not always observed directly, and such information is often transmitted via informal conversations. Our analysis relies on a natural experiment involving exogenously assigned peer groups. Starting in 2008, the Colombian Stock Exchange (CSE) launched a series of professional courses on financial topics;5 the majority focused on equity strategies (the program is discussed in detail in Section 3). Registered individuals were assigned to small sections that spent the duration of each course studying about stock trading in a classroom setting â€“ on average 16 students per class. We combine class records with administrative microdata of stock transactions to distinguish between students with trading experience and those with no trading background. In other words, we observe the trades of students that where active in the stock market before they participate in one of the CSE financial courses. We also observe trades and performance of students that began trading only after completing a course, that is, after interacting with some experienced classmates in their artificially-formed group. Overall, our novel data set combines the official class records and trading activity of 13,730 students from over 1,100 courses between 2008 to 2016. While we accurately observe the stock trades of experienced students, we do not know the specific information shared among classmates. To address this issue, we formalize the role of selective communication by introducing information-transmission-bias in a model of social learning. In the model, potential investors with different trading skills are uncertain about the expected payoffs from trading stocks. These individuals update their beliefs after observing public information in stock prices and the signal from experienced investors in their classroom. The theoretical model allows us to identify a set of testable predictions that are unique to the story of selective communication, relative to predictions from alternative or complementary explanations about investment choices under social interactions. The two unique predictions from the model under selective communication are the following. First, only positive peer outcomes influence investment decisions. Second, peer outcomes promote market participation specially among uninformed individuals. In the model, unskilled investors have low precision in their private information. In turn, they put more weight on outside signals than other better-informed individuals â€“ the marginal effect from the peer signal is higher if an individual is less informed a priori. Consequently, positive peer returns encourage more unskilled than skilled investors to trade stocks. Similarly, under perfect communication, uninformed individuals would be more likely to refrain from trading stocks after hearing about the bad experiences from peers. However, since negative information is not transmitted, both informed and uninformed individuals enter the market at a rate that is independent from peer returns. Overall, the model predicts that the proportion of skilled to unskilled entrants decreases when peer returns are positive, and this ratio is constant when peer returns are negative.6 In our empirical design, we exploit the fact that the representation of students with trading backgrounds, their trades, and past performance vary considerably across groups. We find that students assigned to groups with a high share of experienced classmates are more likely to start trading stocks after completing the course. A one standard deviation increase in the share of experience students in a group, evaluated at the mean of all other variables, increases the likelihood of market participation by three percentage points, an increase of more than 27%. Alternative mechanisms that do not involve social influence are ruled out. For example, time fixed effects control for market-wide news releases and other aggregate shocks that influence market participation. City fixed effects control for systematic regional differences and teacher fixed effects remove the influence from the class instructor. Overall, our baseline results suggest a strong presence of peer effects in our classroom setting. 6 These results hold even in cases where signal receivers internalize the bias in communication. 4

text: To evaluate the empirical predictions from our learning model we proceed as follows: we decompose peersâ€™ performance into negative and positive regions to analyze whether unfavorable peer outcomes influence entry similarly to good outcomes. We find that negative returns do not affect market participation and that the relation between peer returns and entry comes solely from positive peer returns. The effect from positive outcomes is economically meaningful: A one standard deviation increase in peer returns, increases the probability of market entry among inexperienced classmates by 15%. Our second crucial finding is related to the performance of new investors. We find that among market entrants, those that share a classroom with successful peers underperform other investors in their first year of trading. In other words, individuals from groups where peers had positive past performance generate lower market-adjusted returns once they begin trading. Moreover, the performance of new investors declines as we compare courses with higher peer returns.7 On the contrary, we do not find any differences in first-year returns among students that entered the market after taking courses where peers had negative outcomes (or courses where classmates had no trading background). These results are consistent with the hypothesis that selective communication encourages more market entry among uninformed investors. These investors not only generate lower returns on average but are also less likely to continue trading after one year; as investors trade, they might realize that their inherent level of ability is low and decide to exit the stock market (Seru, et al., 2009). An alternative explanation for low returns among new investors might be related to mean reversion in stock prices.8 For example, if individuals systematically buy the best-performing stocks of their peers and large price increases are followed by reversals, new investors would display poor performance. Interestingly, we do not find any herding at the stock level. While individuals appear to be driven to the stock market by the overall performance of successful classmates, they do not trade the same stocks as their peers. In our setting, groups are formed artificially, so relative wealth concerns and utility from joint consumption of an asset are likely smaller that in cases were peers are close and groups have formed endogenously (Bursztyn, et al., 2014). The documented underperformance of new investors in our study appears to be related to individualsâ€™ innate ability, rather than from herding strategies that mechanically generate a drag on performance. Another potential explanation for our findings is that individuals accurately observe peer outcomes but decide to ignore negative signals. This form of information neglect is likely present if individuals overestimate their ability to replicate successful trades from peers, while avoiding peersâ€™ mistakes. To directly test how social communication in our classrooms is related to peer performance, we asked former students if they had any discussions about trading strategies with classmates during the course.9 According to our survey, students engage in more investment conversations with peers during periods of high market volatility, when news about stocks are more salient. Importantly, we find that conversations about investments are more common in courses where peer outcomes are good â€“ 93% of students report investment conversations when peer returns are positive, relative to 79% in courses with negative peer returns and 72% in courses without experienced classmates. In other words, while some negative information might be transmitted, the exchange of investment ideas seems stronger when some students have experienced positive outcomes. Using a classroom enviroment,10 we present novel empirical evidence consistent the view that selective communication plays a key role in financial decisions. We show that social learning can sometimes lead to unfavorable outcomes, especially when peer choices are not perfectly observed by members of the social network. Our analysis contributes to the empirical literature that studies the effects from social interactions on investment (e.g., Hong, et al., 2004; Hong, et al., 2005; Ivkovich & Weisbenner, 2007; Brown, et al., 2008; Li, 2015). Most of this literature focuses on identifying peer effects â€“ whether information or behaviors are transmitted, and on the strength of social contagion. We add to the literature by examining one important aspect of peer effects, i.e., the transmission of investment ideas and its impact on behavior when communication is biased. Closely related to our results, Kaustia & Knupfer (2012) find that only positive returns from neighbors, defined as investors living the same zip code, encourage stock market participation. In our study, social interactions are well-defined by classmates and the time and location of each course. This allows us to design a rich set of empirical tests to evaluate the role of selective communication versus other interpretations. The courses, which on average are composed by 13 students without trading experienced and two with trading background, are small enough so that the influence of peer outcomes is likely strong and not diluted as in large settings. Our findings suggest that in social groups, in order to understand peer effects, it is important to identify the biases that affect the process of information transmission. In our setting, uninformed investors appear to be drawn to active trading by the winning accounts from peers, but they later obtain low returns once they start trading. Finally, our findings are related to the literature on the determinants of individual trading performance. Moreover, active trading could be exacerbated by social interactions as favorable ideas about stock trades are easily disseminated across people (e.g., Barber, et al., 2003; Hong et al., 2004). However, because of self-selection, it is difficult to identify whether peer effects are the key driver in the transmission of active trading strategies. If individuals choose where to work or the type of peers, it is difficult to separate selection from peer effects. Our work contributes to this literature by empirically estimating how trading ideas are transmitted across people. While individuals self-select into CSE courses because of their interest in stock trading, they differ in the exposure to classmates with different trading backgrounds. More broadly, our findings have important policy implications. The goal of the education program was to provide information to improve financial decisions. Contrary to this objective, selective communication among peers disseminates inaccurate signals, promoting misguided ideas about personal investing. There are several important qualifications to the generality of the impact from selective communication on financial decision making. CONCLUSIONS This paper examines how social interactions, and in particular, informal word-of-mouth communication with peers affect an individualâ€™s decision to participate in the stock market. We examine the decision to trade stocks among students in a financial education program. The setting is empirically attractive due to the exogenous assignment of students to groups where peers have experienced different outcomes. We find that a higher share of students with trading background in a given course increases the likelihood that other students start trading actively; an effect that is stronger when peers have experienced large returns. We introduce a model of social learning to distinguish predictions that are unique to a setting where information transmission is biased towards positive outcomes. We show that only positive peer returns affect market entry. Furthermore, we find that students registered for courses where peers had large returns underperform during the first year of active trading relative to other amateur investors. We rule out competing explanations for investor underperformance and show that the evidence is mostly consistent with the idea that selective communication encourages active trading among low-skilled individuals. These investors appear to be drawn to the stock market by successful accounts of classmates but obtain lower returns once they start trading.
